comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/Stewie554|Stewie554]] to last version by Synchronism ([[WP:HG|HG]])

diff.*:
Line 4: Line 4:  
'''Wisdom''' is [[knowledge]], [[understanding]], [[experience]], discretion, and [[Intuition (knowledge)|intuitive understanding]], along with a capacity to apply these qualities well towards finding solutions to [[problem]]s. It is the judicious and purposeful application of knowledge that is valued in society. To some extent the terms wisdom and [[intelligence]] have similar and overlapping meanings. The status of wisdom or [[prudence]] as a [[virtue]] is recognized in [[cultural]], [[philosophical]] and [[religious]] sources.
 
'''Wisdom''' is [[knowledge]], [[understanding]], [[experience]], discretion, and [[Intuition (knowledge)|intuitive understanding]], along with a capacity to apply these qualities well towards finding solutions to [[problem]]s. It is the judicious and purposeful application of knowledge that is valued in society. To some extent the terms wisdom and [[intelligence]] have similar and overlapping meanings. The status of wisdom or [[prudence]] as a [[virtue]] is recognized in [[cultural]], [[philosophical]] and [[religious]] sources.

==Psychological perspectives==
  +
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 49, 607–62.</ref>
  +
These analyses indicate that although "there is an overlap of the implicit theory of wisdom with intelligence, perceptiveness, spirituality and shrewdness, it is evident that wisdom is a distinct term and not a composite of other terms."<ref>Brown, S. C., & Greene, J. A. (2006). The Wisdom Development Scale: Translating the conceptual to the concrete. Journal of College Student Development, 47, 1–19.</ref>
  +   +   +   +
===Positive psychology===
  +
Researchers in [[positive psychology]] have defined wisdom (a.k.a. '''psychological perspective''') as the coordination of "knowledge and experience" and "its deliberate use to improve well being."<ref name="CSV106">{{cite book
  +
| last = Peterson
  +
| first = Christopher
  +
| coauthors = [[Martin Seligman|Seligman, Martin E. P.]]
  +
| title = [[Character Strengths and Virtues (Book)|Character strengths and virtues: A handbook and classification]].
  +
| publisher = [[Oxford University Press]]
  +
| date = 2004
  +
| location = Oxford
  +
| page = 106
  +
| isbn = 0-19-516701-5}}</ref> With this definition, wisdom can be measured using the following criteria.<ref name="CSVperspective" />
  +
* A wise person can discern the core of important problems.
  +
* A wise person has [[self-knowledge]].
  +
* A wise person seems [[Sincerity|sincere]] and direct with others.
  +
* Others ask wise people for advice.
  +
* A wise person's actions are consistent with his/her ethical beliefs.
  +
Measurement instruments that use these criteria have acceptable to good [[internal consistency]] and low [[test-retest]] [[Reliability (statistics)|reliability]] (''[[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|r]]'' in the range of 0.35 to 0.67).<ref name="CSVperspective">{{cite book
  +
| last = Harter
  +
| first = Andrew C.
  +
| title = [[Character Strengths and Virtues (Book)|Character strengths and virtues: A handbook and classification]].
  +
| editor = Peterson, Christopher and [[Martin Seligman|Seligman, Martin E. P.]]
  +
| publisher = [[Oxford University Press]]
  +
| chapter = 8
  +
| date = 2004
  +
| location = Oxford
  +
| page = 181-196
  +
| isbn = 0-19-516701-5}}</ref>
  +   +
Many, but not all, studies find that adults' self-ratings of perspective/wisdom do not depend on age.<ref name="CSVperspective" /><ref name="Orwoll">{{cite book|last=Orwoll|first=L.|coauthors=Perlmutter, M.|title=Wisdom: Its nature, origins, and development|editor=R. J. Sternberg|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|date=1990|pages=160–177|isbn=0521367182}}</ref> This stands in contrast to the popular notion that wisdom increases with age.<ref name="Orwoll" />
